text: Morning mist drifted down from the distant hills, spilling along the stone-paved streets and into the heart of the town. Inside the inn, the air carried a faint scent of burnt wood.
I stood behind the counter, polishing a glass. The world outside was blurred by fog, the hanging lamp swaying gently overhead.
This was the calmest moment of every day—before the travelers arrived, when only the sound of glass and my own breathing filled the room.
Sometimes I wondered if I existed only for this: that fleeting peace before the world remembered to wake up, the illusion that even time might pity you for a while.
But that day was different.
The door burst open, a blast of cold air sweeping in, carrying the mixed scents of snow and rust. The wooden door slammed against the wall, shattering the quiet of the tavern.
“Your ale any good? Give me a bottle—I’ll judge it myself!”
He wore a filthy leather cuirass, a broken mercenary insignia hanging from his neck. He looked like he’d crawled straight out of the ruins.
“Drinking this early? The town guard’s on patrol. I thought you people weren’t allowed to drink on duty.”
“Another drink! Or I’ll burn this dump down with me!”
His eyes were murky, like oil on water. The stench of rot and gunpowder clung to him.
A few guests backed into the corner, frightened. Before I could speak, the sound of boots clicked from outside.
“I hear someone’s planning to burn a tavern.” The voice was clear—sharp as snow striking iron.
A woman in a silver-white cloak stepped inside. Sunlight followed her in, catching the faint gleam of her armor.
She was tall and poised, a sword at her side etched with intricate runes. A weathered lily emblem rested on her shoulder.
Her gaze was calm, yet impossible to ignore.
“Good morning.”
Her voice was clear and steady—not forceful, yet it commanded silence all the same.
She walked up to the drunk, step by step. He froze for a second before barking, “Get lost! Mind your own damn business—”
Before he could finish, she raised her hand and traced a motion through the air. The air shifted—then the bottle in his grasp floated free, landing neatly in her palm.
For a heartbeat, the entire tavern seemed to hold its breath. Even the fire flickered, subdued.

options.text: Option A: Step forward and intervene. [Charisma Check DC 4]
Option B: Stay quiet and watch what happens. [No Check Required]
Option C: Subtly reach for the short sword behind the counter. [Strength Check DC 6]
